q: Mention the adaptations of wind-pollinated flowers.
a: Wind-pollinated flowers, or anemophilous flowers, are adapted to increase the chances of pollination without attracting insects. They are typically small and inconspicuous, lacking bright colors, nectar, and fragrance. The pollen grains are produced in very large quantities, are lightweight and non-sticky to be easily carried by wind. The stigma is often large, feathery, and well-exposed to efficiently trap airborne pollen.

q: Define a clone. Write about one advantage and one disadvantage of a clone.
a: A clone is a group of morphologically and genetically identical organisms produced from a single parent through asexual reproduction. A significant \textbf{advantage} is the preservation and rapid multiplication of desirable parental traits, such as high yield or disease resistance. A major \textbf{disadvantage} is the lack of genetic variation, which makes the entire population equally vulnerable to new diseases or changes in the environment.

q: What are the names of the component cells of the embryo sac?
a: A mature angiosperm embryo sac typically consists of a seven-celled, eight-nucleate structure. These components are: the \textbf{egg apparatus} at the micropylar end (comprising one egg cell and two synergids), three \textbf{antipodal cells} at the chalazal end, and one large \textbf{central cell} in the middle, which contains two polar nuclei.

q: What do you understand by emasculation? Why is it done?
a: Emasculation is the surgical removal of anthers from a bisexual flower before the pollen matures, without damaging the female reproductive part (pistil). This technique is a crucial step in artificial hybridization. It is performed to prevent unwanted self-pollination and to allow for controlled cross-pollination with pollen from a desired male parent, which is essential for developing new plant varieties with specific traits.

q: Tell about false fruit with an example.
a: A false fruit, or pseudocarp, is a fruit that develops from floral parts other than the ovary. While a true fruit develops exclusively from the ovary, in a false fruit, other parts like the thalamus or receptacle grow to become the main fleshy and edible portion. A common example is the apple, where the part we eat is the succulent thalamus, not the ovary.

q: Give the definition of monocarpic fruits with an example.
a: Monocarpic plants are those that flower, set fruit, and produce seeds only once in their lifetime before dying. The fruits they produce are thus referred to as monocarpic fruits. This strategy involves the plant investing all of its resources into a single, massive reproductive event. Well-known examples of monocarpic plants include bamboo and agave.

q: Explain false fruit with an example.
a: A false fruit is a fruit in which the fleshy, edible part is derived from tissues other than the ovary, such as the thalamus or receptacle. This is in contrast to a true fruit, which develops solely from the ovary. A well-known example is the strawberry, where the red, fleshy part is the swollen receptacle, and the actual tiny 'seeds' on the surface are the true fruits (achenes).

q: Write a short note on asexual reproduction in organisms.
a: Asexual reproduction is a mode of reproduction involving a single parent that results in offspring that are genetically identical to the parent, known as clones. This process does not involve the fusion of gametes. It is a common and rapid method of multiplication in many organisms, including single-celled organisms (like bacteria via fission, yeast via budding) and many plants (via vegetative propagation).

q: Explain asexual reproduction in an organism with the help of example.
a: Asexual reproduction is a method of creating new individuals from a single parent, without the involvement of gametes. The offspring are genetically identical to the parent. For instance, \textit{Hydra} reproduces asexually through budding. A small bud develops as an outgrowth on the parent's body, grows into a miniature hydra, and eventually detaches to lead an independent life.

q: Define the following: (i) Protozoan endoparasite (ii) Ovule
a: (i) \textbf{Protozoan endoparasite:} A single-celled eukaryotic organism (protozoan) that lives inside the body of another organism (the host) and obtains nourishment from it, such as \textit{Plasmodium}, which causes malaria in humans. (ii) \textbf{Ovule:} The structure within the ovary of a flowering plant that contains the female gamete (egg cell) and, after fertilization, develops into the seed.

q: Define and give one example of each of the following. (i) False fruit (ii) True fruit (iii) Parthenogenic fruits (iv) Polyembryony
a: (i) \textbf{False Fruit:} A fruit developing from floral parts besides the ovary. Example: Apple. (ii) \textbf{True Fruit:} A fruit developing solely from the ovary. Example: Mango. (iii) \textbf{Parthenocarpic Fruit:} A fruit that develops without fertilization, and is thus seedless. Example: Banana. (iv) \textbf{Polyembryony:} The occurrence of more than one embryo in a single seed. Example: Citrus.

q: What is the importance of embryosac in angiospermic plants?
a: The embryo sac is fundamentally important in angiosperms as it is the site of fertilization. It contains the female gamete (egg cell) which fuses with a male gamete to form the zygote. It also houses the polar nuclei, which fuse with the second male gamete to form the primary endosperm nucleus, giving rise to the endosperm. The endosperm provides the vital nutrition required for the development of the embryo.

q: Show the well labelled diagram of an angiospermic 8-nucleate embryo-sac.
a: A diagram of a mature embryo sac shows an oval structure containing: at the micropylar end, an \textbf{egg apparatus} (one egg cell and two synergids with filiform apparatus); at the chalazal end, three \textbf{antipodal cells}; and in the center, a large \textbf{central cell} with two \textbf{polar nuclei}.

q: Define cross-pollination with the help of suitable example.
a: Cross-pollination, or xenogamy, is the transfer of pollen grains from the anther of a flower on one plant to the stigma of a flower on a different plant of the same species. It is crucial for promoting genetic diversity. A suitable example is maize, which is monoecious but relies on wind to carry pollen from the tassel (male flower) of one plant to the silk (stigma) of another.

q: What do you understand by parthenogenesis ? Explain with example.
a: Parthenogenesis is a natural form of asexual reproduction where an embryo develops from an unfertilized ovum. This process leads to the development of an individual without fertilization. For example, in honeybees, the male drones are produced from unfertilized, haploid eggs laid by the queen bee, while the female bees develop from fertilized eggs.

A typical microsporangium (pollen sac) has a circular structure surrounded by four protective wall layers: the outermost \textbf{epidermis}, followed by the \textbf{endothecium}, one to three \textbf{middle layers}, and the innermost nutritive layer called the \textbf{tapetum}. The center of the microsporangium is filled with sporogenous tissue, whose cells develop into pollen grains.

Double fertilization is a distinctive feature of angiosperms. It involves two fusion events within the embryo sac: 1) \textbf{Syngamy}, where one male gamete fuses with the egg cell to form the diploid ($2n$) zygote. 2) \textbf{Triple Fusion}, where the second male gamete fuses with the two polar nuclei in the central cell to form the triploid ($3n$) primary endosperm nucleus, which develops into the endosperm.

q: What is double fertilisation? in which plant group does it occur?
a: Double fertilization is a complex reproductive process unique to \textbf{angiosperms} (flowering plants). It consists of two separate fusions: the first is the fusion of one male gamete with the egg cell to form the zygote ($2n$), and the second is the fusion of the other male gamete with the two polar nuclei to form the primary endosperm nucleus ($3n$).

Polyembryony is the condition where two or more embryos develop from a single fertilized egg or within a single seed. This can occur due to the cleavage of the zygote or the development of embryos from other cells in the ovule, like the nucellus. A common example where polyembryony is observed is in \textbf{citrus} fruits like oranges and lemons.
